abstract.p: Barbara Spitzer letter rebuts Sarah Boxer's July 12 Critic's Notebook column, which took jabs at New York City area's cow sculptures (S)

block.p: I think most New Yorkers, as well as residents of Connecticut and New Jersey, can appreciate the difference between street art and a museum exhibition, so I was surprised by Sarah Boxer's jabs at the New York City area's cow parade (''Cattle Are Standin' Like Statues: Isn't It Time to Put Those Fiberglass Visitors Out to Pasture?'', Critic's Notebook, July 12).
Artists who need money get paid, the companies that sponsor the cows get advertising, viewers are amused and charities ultimately benefit handsomely when the cows are auctioned.

I think most New Yorkers, as well as residents of Connecticut and New Jersey, can appreciate the difference between street art and a museum exhibition, so I was surprised by Sarah Boxer's jabs at the New York City area's cow parade (''Cattle Are Standin' Like Statues: Isn't It Time to Put Those Fiberglass Visitors Out to Pasture?'', Critic's Notebook, July 12).
Artists who need money get paid, the companies that sponsor the cows get advertising, viewers are amused and charities ultimately benefit handsomely when the cows are auctioned.
It seems to me that's a win-win-win situation.
BARBARA SPITZER Woodcliff Lake, N.J., July 12, 2000
